title.native: ブレイブ・ストーリー

description:
When 11 year old Wataru's father leaves home and his mother is taken ill to hospital, he decides to change his fate by travelling through the door shown to him by his friend Mitsuru. In a land of magic and monsters, Wataru must summon all his courage and embark on a journey with several comrades to meet the Goddess of Destiny and change this "mistaken fate".

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Isekai
tags.description: Features characters being transported into an alternate world setting and having to adapt to their new surroundings.

tags.name: Kids
tags.description: Target demographic is young children.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Anthropomorphism
tags.description: Contains non-human character(s) that have attributes or characteristics of a human being.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Medieval
tags.description: Partially or completely set in the Middle Ages or a Middle Ages-inspired setting. Commonly features elements such as European castles and knights.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Monster Boy
tags.description: Prominently features a male character who is a part-monster.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: Nekomimi
tags.description: Humanoid characters with cat-like features such as cat ears and a tail.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Kemonomimi
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid characters with animal ears.

tags.name: Estranged Family
tags.description: At least one family member of the MC intentionally distances themselves or a family distances themselves from a person related to the MC.

tags.name: Dungeon
tags.description: Prominently features a dungeon environment.

tags.name: Suicide
tags.description: The act or an instance of taking or attempting to take one's own life voluntarily and intentionally.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Shapeshifting
tags.description: Features character(s) who changes one's appearance or form.

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Desert
tags.description: Prominently features a desert environment.

tags.name: Circus
tags.description: Prominently features a circus.

title.native: ブレイブ・ストーリー～新説～

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ichirou_o)

Waseda University graduate. Best known as the co-creator of [Code Geass](https://anilist.co/anime/1575/).

[Website](http://www.osawa-office.co.jp/write/miyabe.html) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miyuki_Miyabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%AE%AE%E9%83%A8%E3%81%BF%E3%82%86%E3%81%8D)

Graduated from Sumidagawa High School. She started writing novels at the age of 23.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

The band formed in 2000 after two of the original members met on the internet and discovered that they attended the same university. At their formation with all their current members in 2003, the band's name was Aqua Times, the correct spelling of their current name. No major releases came from the band during this period. The band renamed themselves to Aqua Timez in 2005. Their first release under this name was Sora Ippai ni Kanaderu Inori, a mini-album which charted well on the Oricon.  (Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/千羽由利子)

One of the nine founders of [OLM](https://anilist.co/studio/28/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/千羽由利子)

One of the nine founders of [OLM](https://anilist.co/studio/28/).
_Note: Not to be confused with the [mangaka](https://anilist.co/staff/245226/Yuuichi-Tanaka)._
__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bbkoichi21)__
__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bbkoichi21)__
Juno Reactor is a musical and performing act known for the cinematic fusion of electronic, orchestral, and global music.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tmypg12)
Originating from [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).
**Tomoko Fukunaga** is a Japanese animator and animation director.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/125951990) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/users/877227) | [Fanbox](https://misopetha-menos.fanbox.cc/)

Originating from [Sunshine Corporation](https://anilist.co/studio/7108/).

Close friends with [Shunji Akasaka](https://anilist.co/staff/157902/)

Heavily inspired by [Tatsuya Yoshihara](https://anilist.co/staff/112047/), he follows him in most of his series, such as [Black Clover](https://anilist.co/anime/97940/), [Monster Musume no Iru Nichijou](https://anilist.co/anime/21093/) and [Namiuchigiwa no Muromisan](https://anilist.co/anime/16910/) on which he worked as an Animator, Animation Director or Character Designer.

He is best known for his work as a Chief Animation Director on Black Clover, and he has a deep respect for [Yuuki Tabata](https://anilist.co/staff/110063/)'s art and tries to transmit it in his corrections with his friend [Shunji Akasaka](https://anilist.co/staff/157902/).

Originating from [Sunshine Corporation](https://anilist.co/studio/7108/).

Close friends with [Takaya Sunagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/157903/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/739726003056955393)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田真宏_(アニメ監督%29)

A prominent anime creator and one of the founders of studio [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/).

While still in university, Maeda was part of a manga club together with [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/), during which both of them got invited to participate on [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and [Daicon IV](https://anilist.co/anime/121664/). This brought Maeda enough recognition to get invited on the production of [Nausicaä](https://anilist.co/anime/572/), and the subseqeunt late '80s [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) films. He also worked on [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s projects during this time.

In 1992, after having completely cut ties with Ghibli due to differences in working methods, Maeda founded Gonzo together with [Shinji Higuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/107646/), [Hiroshi Yamaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/97308/) and [Shouji Murahama](https://anilist.co/staff/119708/), who were Gainax employees he had previously worked with on [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). At Gonzo he debuted as a director in 1998 with [Blue Submarine No.6](https://anilist.co/anime/1051/).

In 2004, Maeda directed [Gankutsuou](https://anilist.co/anime/239/), an adaptation of an 1844 novel, The Count of Monte Cristo, by [Alexandre Dumas](https://anilist.co/staff/102535/). Initially Maeda wanted to adapt an Alfred Bester novel, The Stars My Destination, but was rejected by the novel's copyright holders after proposing the numerous changes he wanted to make to the original narrative. He then searched for another work he could adapt into a science fiction setting and ended up going with The Count of Monte Cristo. The series was praised by Western critics and received multiple international accolades.

Called one of the most imaginative visualists in anime by Helen McCarthy, a British anime reference book author.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Known to have been a close friend of [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s before his passing.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田真宏_(アニメ監督%29)

A prominent anime creator and one of the founders of studio [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/).

He then searched for another work he could adapt into a science fiction setting and ended up going with The Count of Monte Cristo. The series was praised by Western critics and received multiple international accolades.

Called one of the most imaginative visualists in anime by Helen McCarthy, a British anime reference book author.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Known to have been a close friend of [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s before his passing.

Hiroshi Shirai is a Japanese CG artist, animator and director. He was formerly affiliated with [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/GONZO). After graduating from Digital Hollywood, he joined Gonzo's digital division and contributed in the CGI animation production for many of Gonzo's projects, those including [Blue Submarine No. 6](https://anilist.co/anime/1051/Blue-Submarine-No-6/), [Melty Lancer THE ANIMATION](https://anilist.co/anime/1155/Melty-Lancer-THE-ANIMATION/), [Vandread](https://anilist.co/anime/180/Vandread/) and [Yukikaze](https://anilist.co/anime/1080/Yukikaze/).

In 2009, when Gonzo sold its digital division to Q-tec. He along with 24 other former Gonzo employees became part of the newly established animation studio [Graphinica](https://anilist.co/studio/894/Graphinica) and has remained there since.

Outside the anime industry, Shirai also worked on video games such as Nintendo's Xenoblade Chronicles series and The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild under Graphinica.

__Notable works outside anime:__
~!
- Xenoblade Chronicles (Video Game, 2010), (Cinematics: Lead Animation)
- Xenoblade Chronicles X (Video Game, 2015), (Cutscenes: Cutscene Direction, Storyboards)
- The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild (Video Game, 2017), (Assistant Cinematic Directors) 
- Xenoblade Chronicles 2 (Video Game, 2017), (Cinematic Direction, Cutscenes: Cutscene Direction, Cutscene Storyboarding)
- Xenoblade Chronicles 3 (Video Game, 2022), (Cinematic Directors, Cutscene Director, Cutscene Storyboard Artists) !~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/t_bamboo)

He grew up in Mexico because of his parents' work. In elementary school he read Ishinomori Shoutarou's Cyborg 009. Later he experienced the Yamato and Gundam boom, prompting him to be interested in animation. He started working as background artist, later becoming freelance. During that time Takeda got acquainted with Tokuhiro Hiragi and Tatsuya Kushida, whom he then helped establishing the art studio Bihou in 1993.

In 2005 he established the independent art studio Bamboo, which became a company in 2007.

(Source: AniDB)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田真宏_(アニメ監督%29)
